Recognizing and modifying the acid property-dependent catalytic characteristics of catalysts are of great importance for Prins condensation reaction. Herein, a series of metal-doped M-NH4-PW catalysts (M=Pt, Fe, Ir, Ru) are successfully synthesized for Prins condensation reaction of formaldehyde and propylene to produce 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane. Our findings demonstrate that the catalytic performance of M-NH4-PW catalysts is influenced by the chemical nature of metal site properties with different electron transfer abilities. Specifically, the new Lewis acid decorated by Pt metal on 4-H site is more favorable for the selective adsorption of formaldehyde and activation of its CO bond. Additionally, the synergistic effect between Pt metal sites and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− promotes the formation of CC bonds between protonated formaldehyde and propylene. Consequently, the Pt-NH4-PW catalyst exhibits high conversion (> 80 %) and simultaneous selectivity towards 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane selectivity (65 %). This strategy may provide valuable insights for developing efficient multifunctional catalysts for Prins condensation reactions. Graphical abstract The synergistic effect between metal sites and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− promotes the formation of 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane through the formaldehyde-propylene Prins condensation. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phosphotungstate Lewis acid site Prins condensation reaction 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane (4MD) serves as an industrially versatile pharmaceutical intermediate, chemical raw material, and chemical intermediate in the production of 1,3-butanediol which is widely employed as an important monomer for cosmetics, antibiotics and polyester resins [1,2]. It can be prepared via the deborination of heterocyclic system through carbonyl compounds reacting with 1,3-dioxa-2-boronocycloalkanes, and condensation reaction of aldehydes with diols [3], suffering from high production costs and scarcity of raw materials. The Prins condensation reaction of formaldehyde and propylene offers a more environmentally friendly and cost-effective process to produce 4MD [4]. However, the activity of catalyst is limited, and the product distribution becomes intricate due to the complex conditions of the reaction (such as the solvent effect [5,6]) in this alternative process. Therefore, it is crucial to develop catalysts possessing excellent selectivity and catalytic performance for the condensation of formaldehyde and propylene to synthesize 4MD. Initially, homogeneous acid catalysts are considered to catalyze Prins condensation due to their strong acidity. However, they suffer from drawbacks such as corrosiveness, poor recyclability, and environmental pollution [7,8]. Recently, heterogeneous acid catalysts (including zeolites, phosphates, and oxides) have been pursued as potential alternatives that can overcome the aforementioned issues [9–11]. In particular, heteropolyacids (HAPs) with enhanced acidic properties compared to other catalysts contribute to facilitating the protonation of formaldehyde, thus enabling efficient catalysis for Prins condensation reactions of formaldehyde with small molecule olefins [12,13]. Nevertheless, heteropolyacids also exhibit certain limitations including coking [13,14], polymerization of olefins themselves, and low selectivity towards target products due to non-selective adsorption on active acid sites. Therefore, rationally constructing solid acid catalysts for purposeful promotion of reactant adsorption and activation through controlled regulation of catalyst acid properties holds great potential for enhancing the catalytic performance of formaldehyde-propylene condensation to 4MD. Doping metal into phosphotungstate-based materials is known to promote the generation of new metal sites, which can selectively adsorb reactants [15–18]. Talib et al. demonstrated through theoretical calculations that the electronic transfer between metal atoms and PTA clusters, as well as the orbital mixing between metals and surface oxygen, enable excellent reactivity of the metal/PTA catalyst [18]. Specifically, the presence of metals contributes to selective adsorption and activation during catalytic reactions [18]. Furthermore, Lin et al. found that the Jahn-Teller distortion effect promotes electron transfer from NH bonding orbitals of the reactants (such as NH3) to d orbitals of metal atoms, while the synergistic effect between surface oxygen atoms and metal atoms enhances efficient activation of reactants [17]. Based on the literature analysis, doping metals in phosphotungstate is expected to achieve selective adsorption and activation of formaldehyde as well as the CC bond generation with propylene, thereby improving conversion and selectivity in formaldehyde-propylene condensation to 4MD. This further motivates us to clarify the reaction mechanism associated with this kind of catalyst via experimental exploration. Herein, we present a study on the formaldehyde-propylene Prins condensation to 4MD using metal-doped M-NH4-PW (M=Pt, Fe, Ru and Ir) catalysts. The comprehensive characterization of M-NH4-PW catalytic systems highlights the crucial role played by the synergistic effect between M metal site and nearby O in [PW12O40]3−, which enables selective adsorption of formaldehyde at the active site of the catalyst. Notably, Pt-NH4-PW catalysts exhibited superior catalytic performance with a yield of over 50 % for 4MD compared to NH4-PW and other catalysts (Fe, Ru, and Ir-NH4-PW). This methodology provides valuable insights into the proper design of catalysts for Prins condensation of olefins with formaldehyde. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, GR, 99.8 %, Macklin) and phosphotungstic acid hydrate (PTA, H3PW12O40·xH2O, AR, Aladdin) were used to synthesize phosphotungstate carriers. Iron nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 99 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), Ruthenium(III) chloride trihydrate (RuCl3·3H2O, 98 %+, Adamas), Platinum nitrate solution (PtN2O6, Pt, 18.02 %, Aladdin), Iridium(Ⅲ) chloride hydrate (IrCl3·xH2O, 99.9 %, Ir: 54 %, Adamas), Formaldehyde solution(AR, 37 wt.% in H2O with 10–15 % methanol stabilizer), 1,4-dioxane (C4H8O2, ACS, ≥ 99.0 %, Aladdin) and Propylene (Xinkeyuan Gas 99.9 %) were employed. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Catalysts discussed in the paper were synthesized by improving the methods reported in references [19,20]. (NH4)3PW12O40 was synthesized as follows: In 30 mL of ice water, 4 g of PTA was dissolved, obtaining the solution A. In 30 mL of water, 0.223 g of NH4Cl was dissolved, obtaining a solution named B. Under vigorous stirring, solution B was added dropwise into solution A, with careful control over the rate of acceleration of the drops at about 1 mL/min to obtain a white colloidal solution. The obtained white colloidal solution was continuously stirred in an ice bath for 5 h, and then collecting the precipitate by centrifuged (9000 rpm). The precipitate was washed using water then the solid obtained by re-centrifugation was dried at a temperature of 70 °C. Finally, the (NH4)3PW12O40 catalyst (denoted as NH4-PW) was obtained by calcinating in air atmosphere at 250 °C for 30 min. For the preparation of M/(NH4)3PW12O40 catalysts with different doped metals (M=Fe, Ru, Pt, Ir), stoichiometric iron nitrate nonahydrate, Ruthenium(III) chloride trihydrate, Platinum nitrate solution, and Iridium(III) chloride hydrate were mixed with NH4Cl solution, respectively. The resulting mixture was added to the solution of PTA. The synthesis and post-processing procedures followed the same protocol as those for the NH4-PW catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations Several kinds of techniques were employed to analyze catalysts: The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were measured on an X'Pert PRO MPD diffractometer. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi was used to perform X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), which were calibrated using the peak C1S at 284.8 eV. Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) of the catalysts were conducted on Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50. Raman spectra were measured on a Raman LabRAM HR Evolution 325–1000 with a 532 nm laser line. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were recorded on quanta FEG-250 scanning electron microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on the Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin. Pyridine infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) was used on a NEXUS spectrometer to assess the acid kinds of the catalysts. 31P MAS NMR spectra were tested on Bruker 600 M Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer. In situ DRIFTS spectra of CO were obtained on a NEXUS spectrometer to study the adsorption behavior of the catalysts. The CO adsorption temperature of the Pt-NH4-PW catalyst was 80 °C, and the adsorption temperatures of the other catalysts were set to 50 °C in combination with Ref. [21]. The ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) spectra were obtained on the Micromeritics Autochem 2910 to characterize the acid strength of the catalyst. 2.4 Catalytic test A 50 mL high-pressure reactor was used to evaluate the catalysts. Normally, the reactor was filled with propylene to 0.6 MPa after 7.5 mL of 1,4-dioxane, 1.5 mL of formaldehyde solution, and 0.3 g of catalyst were added. The speed of the reaction was 1000 rpm, and the reaction temperature was 120 °C for 6 h. When the reaction was complete, it was cooled to room temperature before collecting the reaction solution. Formaldehyde and formic acid in the reaction solution were analyzed by liquid chromatography, and the column is Rezex (ROA-organic acid H +(8 %), 300 × 7.8 mm). A Scion 456-GC fitted with a KB-624 column and FID detector was used to examine other products in the reaction solution. Gas chromatographic analysis was used to quantify the product by the internal standard method, and the internal standard chosen was n-butanol. The following formulas were used to determine the major selectivity, yield of products and the conversion of the reactant: C R = n PA + MeOH , initial − n PA + MeOH , unreacted n PA + MeOH , initial × 100 % S i = n i n All non − aqueous products × 100 % Y i = C R × S i × 100 % Methylal (DMM) generated by the reaction between formaldehyde and methanol (MeOH) affects the product distribution in this reaction system, so formaldehyde and methanol are used as one kind of reactant to calculate the conversion rate. CR in the formula means the Co-conversion of formaldehyde and methanol, ni means the amount of product i, Si means the selectivity of product i, and Yi means the yield of product i. For ease of presentation, 1,3-Butanediol, formaldehyde, methanol, formic acid, 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane, tetrahydropyran-4-ol and methylal are respectively abbreviated in this thesis as 1,3-BDO, PA, MeOH, FA, 4MD, Oxan-4-ol and DMM. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations The Dmol3 module in the Material Studio 8.0 platform was used to carry out DFT calculations. The phosphotungstates cluster model [PW12O40]3− was derived from the material project website: https://legacy.materialsproject.org/, which is part of the Material Genome Initiative and provides a multitude of structural information for inorganic materials. The monatomic metal M (M=Fe, Ru, Ir, Pt) was placed in the 4-H site of the cluster, which is generally considered to be the most stable support site for the metal [16,22]. Cluster configurations were relaxed to minimize energy and dispersion interactions were taken into account. GGA-PEB was chosen as the exchange-correlation functional, which is often used for calculations of inorganic materials such as phosphotungstates [23,24]. The basis set was a dual-valued pseudo-polarized basis set (DND). In order to ensure that each cluster or molecule was on the bottom of potential energy surface (PES), the electronic processing was set to all-electron, and a frequency analysis was performed. 1.0 × 10–5 Hartree, 0.02 Hartree/nm, and 0.005 Å were the convergence criteria corresponding to energy, gradient, and displacement; further, the calculation precision was set to fine. Formaldehyde and propylene adsorption energies were defined to quantify the effect of clusters on formaldehyde and propylene adsorption. The adsorption energy formula is as follows: Δ E C H 2 O = E cluster − C H 2 O − E cluster − E C H 2 O Δ E C 3 H 6 = E cluster − C 3 H 6 − E cluster − E C 3 H 6 Where Δ E C H 2 O and Δ E C 3 H 6 are the adsorption energies of formaldehyde and propylene, E cluster − C H 2 O and E cluster − C 3 H 6 are the energies of formaldehyde and propylene complexes with clusters, respectively, E C H 2 O and E C 3 H 6 are the energy of formaldehyde and propylene, and E cluster is the energy of monometallic doping energies of phosphotungstate clusters. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Enhanced catalytic performance of the M-NH4-PW catalysts The Prins condensation reaction between formaldehyde and olefins is a highly intricate process, and the acidity properties of the catalyst, as well as the reaction conditions, have a significant impact on both the reaction process and product composition [8,25]. It is widely acknowledged that the activation of formaldehyde to protonated formaldehyde plays a key role in facilitating the Prins condensation reaction between formaldehyde and olefin [26,27]. The nucleophilic addition reaction between protonated formaldehyde and propylene promotes CC formation, which further reacts with additional formaldehyde to generate 4MD (Fig. 1 a). In this study, NH4-PW and M-NH4-PW catalysts with different doped metals were employed to assess their catalytic activity for the Prins condensation reaction between formaldehyde and propylene to 4MD. As depicted in Fig. 1b, both the conversion rate of formaldehyde and 4MD yield are higher for M-NH4-PW catalyst compared to NH4-PW catalyst. Among them, Pt-NH4-PW catalyst exhibits superior performance with a maximum formaldehyde conversion (87 %) and 4MD yield (48 %). These results indicate that more active sites are generated on M-NH4-PW catalysts while also highlighting variations in active sites among different metal-doped M-NH4-PW catalysts. Preliminary findings from these reactions reveal disparities in catalytic performance between NH4-PW and various metal-doped M-NH4-PW catalysts, thereby motivating further investigation into their distinct physical and chemical structures. 3.2 Effect of doped metals on physical properties of catalysts It should be noted that introducing transition metals inevitably impacts the physical structure of catalysts. The influence of doped metals on the characteristic physical structure of NH4-PW and M-NH4-PW (M=Pt, Fe, Ru, and Ir) catalysts was initially investigated using XRD, Raman, and FT-IR techniques. XRD spectra of the catalysts shown in Fig. 2 a display characteristic peaks corresponding to the keggin structure of NH4-PW support [28], with no detectable peaks indicating doped metals due to uniform size distribution [29,30]. Fig. 2b reveals that the catalysts exhibit stretching vibrations absorption peaks at 1000, 986, 897, 535, 231, and 210 cm−1 attributed to W=Ot, W-Oc-W, W-Oe-W (Ot-terminal oxygen, Oc-a corner sharing bridging oxygen atom, Oe-an edge-sharing bridging oxygen atom) of the Keggin ion [PW12O40]3− [31,32]. From Fig. 2c, the catalysts also exhibit stretching absorption modes at 813, 891, 990 and 1080 cm−1 corresponding to W-O-W, W = O, P-Oa (Oa-an oxygen atom bound to three W atoms and a P) respectively of the Keggin ion [PW12O40]3− [32,33]. Notably, the characteristic peak at 1408 cm−1 is attributed to the NH stretching band of NH4 + [34], thus demonstrating the successful introduction of NH4 + into the catalysts. The aforementioned characterization fully confirms that M-NH4-PW catalysts with different doped metals retain their distinctive Keggin structure and further proves that the Keggin structure of the M-NH4-PW catalysts with doped metal has better stability and persistence (Fig. 2d). The morphology, elemental distribution, and pore structure of the catalysts were tested by SEM, EDX mapping, and N2 adsorption-desorption techniques. The morphologies of NH4-PW, Pt-NH4-PW, Fe-NH4-PW, Ir-NH4-PW, and Ru-NH4-PW catalysts are depicted in Figs. 2e, f and S1a. The results demonstrate that the catalysts exhibit a uniform and complete spherical shape consistent with the characteristic morphology of NH4-PW catalyst [20,35]. The characteristic elements (P, O, W, N, Pt, Fe, Ir, Ru) of the catalyst can be observed in Figs. 2g and S2, which confirm successfully self-assembly of NH4 + with PTA cluster to form M-NH4-PW catalysts. Furthermore, the metal elements display a homogeneous distribution throughout the catalyst as no metal particles or clusters are detected [36]. In conclusion, it can be deduced that excellent self-assembled M-NH4-PW catalysts with uniformly dispersed metals have been successfully prepared, which is consistent with FT-IR and XRD results. Additionally, N2 adsorption-desorption curves for the catalysts (Fig. S3 and Table S1) indicate that metal doping does not significantly change their pore structure such as specific surface (89–125 m2g−1) area, pore volume (63–79 cm3kg−1) and average pore size (4–6 nm). The distribution of metals on the catalysts was also investigated by HAADF-STEM and CO DRIFTS. The HAADF-STEM images of Pt-NH4-PW, Fe-NH4-PW, Ir-NH4-PW, and Ru-NH4-PW catalysts shown in Fig. S1b reveal the absence of metal particles at different magnification sizes (20 nm, 10 nm, and 5 nm). It is initially hypothesized that the metals exist as single atoms at the 4-H site of M-NH4-PW catalysts [30,37]. Furthermore, CO DRIFTS spectra for various M-NH4-PW catalysts (Fig. S4) show absorption peaks at 1970 and 2069 cm−1 attributed to OCO formed by adsorption of O from heteropolyacid anions on CO [21]. In addition, an absorption peak observed at 2153 cm−1 may be correlated with W-CO formation. No other absorption peaks are detected on the Fe-NH4-PW catalyst, suggesting lower CO affinity of the metals or lower extinction coefficient for CO adsorption on the undercoordinated metal sites [38]. In case of Ir-NH4-PW catalyst, weak coincidence with OCO absorption peak makes it difficult to observe linear adsorption of CO at the Ir site corresponding to an absorption peak around 2070 cm−1 [39]. For Ru-NH4-PW catalyst, additional absorption peaks are found at 2129 and 2096 cm−1, which can be related to polycarbony species Ruδ+(CO)x adsorbed on oxidized Ru sites [40]. An absorption peak at 2042 cm−1 corresponds to linear adsorption on the Ru site [40,41]. In contrast, a distinct additional absorption peak is observed at 2089 cm−1 in Pt-NH4-PW spectrum indicating possible linear adsorption of CO by a single metal atom [42]. Apart from this observation, no other characteristic absorption peaks are found between 1750 and 2080 cm−1, indicating the presence of metals as single atoms at the 4-H site of M-NH4-PW catalysts [21]. The finding is consistent with the conclusion drawn from HADDF-STEM analysis of M-NH4-PW catalysts. In conclusion, the diverse types of doped metals have no significant effect on the characteristic structure, morphology, and pore structure of the catalysts, proving that alterations in the physical structure are not the primary factors influencing the catalytic performance of the catalysts. It also substantiates that via in situ doping method, uniformly distributed single atoms may have been formed on the 4-H site of M-NH4-PW catalysts, thereby further improving metal atom utilization. 3.3 Effect of doped metals on chemical properties of catalysts 3.3.1 Identification of Lewis acid sites on unsaturated metal in Prins condensation reaction It is crucial to comprehend the improved catalytic activity of these catalysts by investigating the quality and quantity of acid sites. Fig. 3 a illustrates the NH3-TPD profiles, while Table S2 presents the acid amounts of M-NH4-PW and NH4-PW catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3a, the peak at 100 °C corresponds to the desorption of NH3 from weak acid sites, whereas between 500 and 650 °C from strong acid sites [32,43]. Upon doping different metals, it becomes evident that desorption peaks associated with strong acid sites are shifted towards higher temperatures. Specifically, Pt-NH4-PW exhibits a significant offset as its peak increases from 570 °C to approximately 601 °C, while other catalysts demonstrate similar trends: Fe-NH4-PW (599 °C) > Ir-NH4-PW (582 °C) > Ru-NH4-PW (580 °C). Consequently, it can be deduced that doping different metals can enhance the catalyst acid strength to varying degrees due to the introduction of new Lewis acid site decorated by Pt, Fe, Ir, and Ru metals. The amount of strong acids in the catalysts shown in Table S2 increases to different degrees after metal doping. The number of strong acid sites is as follows: Pt-NH4-PW > Fe-NH4-PW > Ir-NH4-PW > Ru-NH4-PW > NH4-PW. The amount of strong acid is positively correlated with the catalytic activity of the catalyst. With the amount of strong acid increasing, both the conversion of PA and the yield of 4MD (except for Fe-NH4-PW) gradually increase (Table S3). Therefore, these results indicate that metal doping not only enhances the acidity strength but also increases the acid amount of the catalyst, resulting in improved catalytic performance. To further evaluate the influence of metal doping on the acidic characteristics of these catalysts, Py-IR analysis was conducted. The Py-IR spectra of the NH4-PW catalyst and various metal-doped M-NH4-PW catalysts are presented in Fig. 3b. The spectra show that the catalysts exhibit three absorption peaks at 1540, 1490 and 1450 cm−1, which correspond to the characteristic adsorption of pyridine at Brönsted acid site, B + L acid site and Lewis acid site [44]. After metal loading, the Lewis acid content of the catalysts increases while the ratio of Brönsted acid to Lewis acid decreases. Specifically, for Pt-NH4-PW catalyst it is approximately 0.16, for NH4-PW catalyst it is 0.336, and for other metal-doped catalysts such as Fe, Ir, Ru it ranges from 0.16–0.336 (Table S4). Therefore, metal doping contributes to an increase in the number of acidic sites of the catalysts with a majority being Lewis acid sites belonging to doped metals. In particular, Fe-NH4-PW catalyst exhibits a Brönsted acid to Lewis acid ratio of 0.302, which is higher than that of the Pt-NH4-PW, Ir-NH4-PW, Ru-NH4-PW but lower than NH4-PW alone. These results demonstrate why Fe-NH4-PW has a lower 4MD yield compared to other metal-loaded catalysts, further indicating that new Lewis acidic sites favor selective generation of the target product due to its preferential adsorption of formaldehyde. In summary, it is concluded that metal loading further effectively improves the performance of catalysts by modifying their acidic properties. Although M-NH4-PW catalysts possess a stronger and more abundant Lewis acid site, this characteristic may not be readily apparent. Alternatively, we infer the existence of synergistic interaction between the M metal site and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− on the M-NH4-PW catalysts [17]. Based on previous reports regarding the Prins condensation reaction of formaldehyde with olefins over Lewis acid catalysts [26,45], as well as incorporating the aforementioned correlations between acid characterization and catalytic activity. Fig. 3c1 and 3c2 depict the reactions of formaldehyde and propylene over NH4-PW and M-NH4-PW catalysts, respectively. The adsorption and activation of formaldehyde at the Lewis acidic site are primary steps of the reaction. Furthermore, on the M-NH4-PW catalyst, O atoms at the 4-H site can accept the H + in the system, enabling simultaneous adsorption of propylene while promoting polarization of its CC bond. This enhances efficiency in nucleophilic addition reactions with protonated formaldehyde to generate CC bonds. In this case, it contributes to reducing the occurrence of side reactions and increasing the rate of the Prins condensation reaction of formaldehyde with propylene. 3.3.2 Identification of the synergistic effect between M metal site and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− It is highly possible that M-NH4-PW catalysts preferentially employ transition metals to modify their acid sites associated with the electron transfer of metals and the support, thereby promoting Prins condensation reaction of propylene and formaldehyde. Consequently, XPS and 31P MAS NMR determined surface electronic properties to gain insights into the nature of electron transfer between metals and the support over M-NH4-PW catalysts. Fig. 4 a and 4b illustrate the XPS spectra of P 2p and W 4f for both M-NH4-PW and NH4-PW catalysts, respectively. The presence of a broad peak ranging from 133.8–135.1 eV in Fig. 4a indicates the existence of P5+ in an oxidized state [46], while two broad peaks between 38.3–39 eV (4f5/2) and 36.1–36.8 eV (4f7/2) in Fig. 4b suggest the presence of W6+species within these catalysts [47]. These results are consistent with the state of P and W ions within the Keggin structure of the PTA cluster [48,49]. Furthermore, since W(VI) cations are the metal cations in the NH4-PW, it can be inferred that highly electron-deficient W (VI) cations contribute to Lewis acid site formation in NH4-PW [50]. NH4-PW and M-NH4-PW catalysts with different peaks for both P 2p and W 4f indicate the presence and strength of interactions between various metals and support [20,51]. According to Table S5, it can be found that compared to NH4-PW, the binding energy peaks (P 2p, W 4f) of Pt-NH4-PW, Ir-NH4-PW, and Ru-NH4-PW have shifted towards higher values. The order of binding energy for P 2p and W 4f5/2 on these three catalysts is as follows: Pt (134.85 eV) < Ir (134.96 eV) < Ru (135.10 eV), Pt (38.82 eV) < Ir (38.90 eV) < Ru (39.00 eV). This confirms that electrons transfer from the support to metals, with Ir and Ru exhibiting the highest degree of transfer. It potentially leads to a decrease in the metal's electrophilic capacity, resulting in weaker Lewis acid properties. Consequently, compared to Ir-NH4-PW and Ru-NH4-PW catalysts, Pt-NH4-PW exhibits superior acidic strength. The strong Lewis acid sites have been reported to exhibit significant water adsorption in this reaction system, leading to hydrolysis dissociation and subsequent generation of protons and hydroxide ions [4,52,53]. On this basis, the surface oxygen atoms surrounding the doped metal center carry more negative charges, rendering them more basic compared to other oxygen atoms on the support's surface. This enhanced basicity enables them to accept protons generated from hydrolysis when compared to NH4-PW catalysts [17]. The formation of both Lewis (metal atom) and Brönsted acid sites (O atom of 4-H on the support) on the M-NH4-PW catalyst due to the synergistic effect between metal and support promotes protonated formaldehyde generation as well as propylene polarization. It contributes significantly towards improving direct CC bond formation between formaldehyde and propylene. However, the peak of Fe-NH4-PW catalyst (Fig. 4a, b) shifts towards lower binding energy due to the pronounced electron transfer from the metal to the support compared with other catalysts (Pt, Ir, Ru-NH4-PW) [37], resulting in more electrophilic and stronger Lewis acid sites. Consequently, the O atom belonging to the 4-H site becomes more receptive to H + during hydrolysis of Fe ions by hydration water molecules [50,53]. Therefore, the Fe-NH4-PW catalyst possesses a greater number of Brönsted acid sites in comparison to other catalysts. These Brönsted acid sites may not be selectively activated for reaction substrates, which prevents efficient conversion of carbon-positive ion intermediate into 4MD in a directed manner. As a result, despite exhibiting high conversion rates, the Fe-NH4-PW catalyst demonstrates low selectivity towards product formation. In addition, hydroxide can bind to Fe through electron transfer leading to decreased acidity strength and amount compared to Pt-NH4-PW. This further indicates that while NH4-PW catalyst possesses Lewis and Brönsted acid sites individually, their lack of synergistic effect results in inferior performance compared with M-NH4-PW. Besides, this demonstrates that multifunctional catalysts with synergistic active sites [54,55], due to the interaction between the metal and the support, may be suitable for the Prins condensation reactions of formaldehyde with small molecule olefins. Fig. 4c shows the 31P MAS NMR spectra of NH4-PW and M-NH4-PW catalysts, commonly employed for detecting alterations in the chemical environment surrounding P in heteropolyacids [37]. The spectra reveal discernible variations in the chemical shifts of P belonging to NH4-PW and M-NH4-PW catalysts. Among them, the chemical shift of P in NH4-PW is approximately −15.30 ppm, representing the signal peak corresponding to PO4 tetrahedrons with a characteristic Keggin structure [56]. Conversely, the chemical shift of P for M-NH4-PW ranges from −15.26 and −15.40 ppm, differing from that observed of NH4-PW. This discrepancy suggests a modification in the chemical environment surrounding P due to electron transfer between the metal and support. Moreover, it implies an alteration in electron cloud density around P leading to absorption peak shifts towards different magnetic field orientations. This result is in agreement with that of XPS. In summary, compared to the NH4-PW catalysts, metal doping induces the generation of Lewis acid sites through the interaction of metal and support (Fig. 4d). Meanwhile, these newly formed Lewis acidic sites exhibit a higher electron accepting capacity from CO compared to the Brönsted acidic sites, which in turn can selectively activate formaldehyde and reduce the competing adsorption of propylene and formaldehyde. Moreover, the interaction between the metal and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− facilitates H + adsorption, leading to propylene polarization. Thus, the synergistic interaction with metal sites promotes CC bond generation between formaldehyde and propylene while enhancing catalytic performance. The Pt-NH4-PW catalyst contains strong acidity and an abundant amount of acid due to moderate electron transfer between metal and support, consequently resulting in improved catalytic performance. 3.4 Calculation of selective adsorption at Lewis acid sites on M-NH4-PW catalysts The previous characterization demonstrated that the loading of metal affected the chemical properties of the catalysts, thereby resulting in variations in their catalytic activity. To further demonstrate these differences, we combined an analysis of the adsorption status of reactants at active sites. Fig. 5 a presents a schematic representation of the adsorption structure for formaldehyde or propylene molecules over Pt-NH4-PW catalyst. When considering the adsorption energy of different metal-loaded M-NH4-PW catalysts as shown in Fig. 5b, it becomes evident that the adsorption energy is higher when two formaldehyde molecules are absorbed compared to one formaldehyde molecule alone. Therefore, it can be inferred that absorbing two formaldehyde molecules represents optimal adsorption conditions. Additionally, the adsorption energy for propylene adsorption is lower than those for absorbing two formaldehyde molecules, proving that catalyst active sites can selectively adsorb formaldehyde. This finding further supports previous characterization and analysis regarding selective formaldehyde adsorption at newly formed Lewis acid sites. Additionally, DFT calculations were conducted using Pt-NH4-PW catalyst as an example to explain the synergistic interaction between the metal and nearby O in [PW12O40]3−. The interaction between the d-orbitals of Pt and the p-orbitals of O, analyzed based on the density-of-states diagrams, is presented in Fig. S5. As can be observed, there is a significant overlap between the Pt-d orbitals and the O-p orbitals at the Fermi energy level, indicating a strong interaction between Pt and O. The strong Pt-O bond results in the transfer of electrons between the Pt atoms and O atoms in the clusters, which makes Pt have Lewis acid properties, and nearby O in [PW12O40]3−naturally accepts a proton. According to this study, the adsorption-activation of CO belonging to formaldehyde is a vital step in this reaction [27]. Furthermore, due to the synergistic effect between metals and nearby O atoms in [PW12O40]3− promoting CC bond formation between protonated formaldehyde and polarization of propylene, M-NH4-PW catalysts exhibit higher selectivity and conversion compared to NH4-PW. The specific adsorption energy of the M-NH4-PW catalysts is presented in Table S6. As can be seen that the Pt-NH4-PW catalyst exhibits a higher adsorption energy for formaldehyde (−57.87 kcal/mol) compared to the Fe-NH4-PW catalyst (−41.12 kcal/mol), while demonstrating a lower adsorption energy than the Ir-NH4-PW catalyst (−69.77 kcal/mol). Among other metals, it belongings to medium adsorption category. Additionally, the Pt-NH4-PW catalyst shows a lower adsorption energy for propylene (−35.77 kcal/mol) compared to Ir-NH4-PW (−46.64 kcal/mol) and Ru-NH4-PW (−46.09 kcal/mol), indicating weak adsorption characteristics. Notably, when considering two formaldehyde molecules, the Pt-NH4-PW catalyst exhibits an even higher adsorption energy (−57.87 kcal/mol), which is four times higher compared to that of single formaldehyde adsorption (−14.10 kcal/mol). This results in a more stable adsorption configuration and stronger selective adsorption of formaldehyde than other catalysts, ultimately leading to enhanced catalytic activity. These findings are consistent with previous descriptions regarding the catalytic activity of M-NH4-PW catalysts. The DFT calculations indicate that Lewis acid sites generated through metal-support interactions contribute to the selective adsorption and subsequent activation of formaldehyde molecules. Furthermore, the synergistic effect between M metal site and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− promotes the generation of the CC bond between protonated formaldehyde and polarized propylene. It is also revealed that the combined effects of selective adsorption, formaldehyde activation, and synergistic interactions of the metal and support notably enhance the catalytic performance over M-NH4-PW catalysts. 3.5 Structure-dependent reaction on the Pt-NH4-PW catalysts Previous characterizations and DFT calculations have elucidated the factors contributing to differences in catalytic activity of the M-NH4-PW catalysts with varying metal loadings, and the results are consistent with previous evaluations of catalytic activity. To further enhance the catalytic performance, reaction conditions for Prins condensation reaction between propylene and formaldehyde over Pt-NH4-PW catalyst were optimized. The Prins condensation reaction of propylene and formaldehyde is a complex process in which the reaction conditions significantly impact the product distribution and reactant conversion. Fig. 6 a illustrates that the conversion rate of formaldehyde initially increases and then decreases as the reaction temperature rises. It has been reported that this condensation reaction between propylene and formaldehyde is exothermic, meaning that high temperature is unfavorable for driving the reaction forward [4]. Moreover, there is an initial increase in 4MD selectivity that is followed by a drop as the reaction temperature rises, reaching its highest value at 120 °C. However, when temperatures exceed 120 °C, side reactions become intensified, leading to the generation of 3-Buten-1-ol, which further reacts with formaldehyde to form Oxan-4-ol [25]. Furthermore, elevated temperatures result in hydrolysis of 4MD into 1,3-BDO and facilitate DMM formation via condensation of formaldehyde with MeOH, consequently decreasing selectivity towards the target product [4,57]. Moreover, Fig. 6b demonstrates that increasing formaldehyde concentration initially enhances its conversion but subsequently leads to a decline, inversely affecting selectivity of 4MD. At low concentrations, formaldehyde fails to fully occupy active site, resulting in lower conversion. Conversely, when concentration surpasses 2.1 mol/L, inadequate active sites in catalyst lead to decreased conversion of formaldehyde while reducing self-condensation side reactions. Simultaneous increasing concentrations promote disproportionation of formaldehyde to MeOH and FA (formic acid), intensifying their condensation reactions with each other. Fig. 6c illustrates the trend of reactant conversion and product selectivity with reaction time for the Prins condensation reaction of propylene and formaldehyde. With the prolongation of the reaction time, the gradual increase in formaldehyde conversion can be attributed to enhanced contact between formaldehyde and catalyst active sites. However, beyond 6 h of reaction time, the increase in formaldehyde conversion becomes less obvious, resulting in intensified side reactions that negatively impact the selectivity of 4MD. Therefore, the optimal reaction time is 6 h. Additionally, Fig. 6d demonstrates the influence of propylene pressure on reactant conversion and product selectivity in this reaction. With increasing propylene pressure, there is a gradual rise in formaldehyde conversion, indicating that an excess amount of propylene promotes the reaction. Nevertheless, when the pressure exceeds 0.6 MPa, conversions tend to level off while simultaneously causing a decrease in selectivity of 4MD due to presumed polymerization reactions leading to by-product formation. The exploration of reaction conditions mentioned above has revealed that the modulation of these conditions is also the key for improving the efficiency of the reaction. The deduction of the subsequent reaction pathway (Fig. 7 ) was based on this exploration, and through optimization of the reaction conditions, a conversion rate nearly 80 % and a yield exceeding 50 % for the target product 4MD were achieved. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have developed different metal-doped M-NH4-PW catalysts that are enriched with Lewis acid site to promote Prins condensation reaction between formaldehyde and propylene to 4MD. The introduction of metal doping generates a significant number of Lewis acid sites with varying electron transfers, thereby strengthening their electron-accepting properties. During the catalytic evaluation, the abundance of Lewis acid sites in M-NH4-PW catalysts and their catalytic activity have a positive correlation. The evidence that the Lewis acid sites of metals on M-NH4-PW catalysts can selectively adsorb formaldehyde and activate its CO bond is provided by further characterization. Alternatively, the synergistic effect between the M metal site and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− further promotes the generation of a CC bond between protonated formaldehyde and polarized propylene. As a result, Pt-NH4-PW exhibits superior catalytic activity (CPA > 80 %) and 4MD yield (> 50 %) for formaldehyde-propylene condensation compared to other catalysts because of its higher abundance of Lewis acid sites. This study serves as a reference for rationally designing catalysts for Prins condensation reactions involving formaldehyde with other olefins. coredata.dc:description: Recognizing and modifying the acid property-dependent catalytic characteristics of catalysts are of great importance for Prins condensation reaction. Herein, a series of metal-doped M-NH4-PW catalysts (M=Pt, Fe, Ir, Ru) are successfully synthesized for Prins condensation reaction of formaldehyde and propylene to produce 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane. Our findings demonstrate that the catalytic performance of M-NH4-PW catalysts is influenced by the chemical nature of metal site properties with different electron transfer abilities. Specifically, the new Lewis acid decorated by Pt metal on 4-H site is more favorable for the selective adsorption of formaldehyde and activation of its CO bond. Additionally, the synergistic effect between Pt metal sites and nearby O in [PW12O40]3− promotes the formation of CC bonds between protonated formaldehyde and propylene. Consequently, the Pt-NH4-PW catalyst exhibits high conversion (> 80 %) and simultaneous selectivity towards 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane selectivity (65 %). This strategy may provide valuable insights for developing efficient multifunctional catalysts for Prins condensation reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-doped M-NH4-PW catalyst with enhanced electron transfer for formaldehyde-propylene condensation to 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane
